conclusion: Determine heat transferred using first law of thermodynamics and properties of ideal gases.
Process A to B is isochoric; volume remains constant at V = 1 x 10^-3 m^3.
Process B to C is isobaric; pressure remains constant at P = 1 x 10^5 Pa.
Work done in process A to B is zero because there is no change in volume.
Calculate work done in process B to C using W = P ΔV.
From graph: P = 1 x 10^5 Pa, ΔV = 2 x 10^-3 m^3.
Change in internal energy ΔU for ideal gas: ΔU = nC_V ΔT.
Temperature at state A: T_A = 27°C = 300 K.
Calculate temperature at state B using ideal gas law: T_B = 100 K.
Calculate temperature at state C using ideal gas law: T_C = 300 K.
Heat transferred in process A to B: Q_AB = -300nR.
Heat transferred in process B to C: Q_BC = 300nR + 200 J.
Total heat transferred Q = Q_AB + Q_BC = 200 J.
Final answer: Total heat transferred by the gas is 200 J.
